author: MMALinker
title: Vitor Belfort argues why he’s at his best moment despite losing skid
text: Esther Lin, MMA Fighting Don’t ask Vitor Belfort if he’s in a bad moment of his career. The former UFC champion headlines UFC Fight Night: Fortaleza on March 11 against rising talent Kelvin Gastelum , and Belfort grew upset when recently asked what he was doing to bounce back from a 1-3 run in his last four UFC fights. "Who said that? Who said it’s a complicated (moment)?” Belfort replied when asked by MMA Fighting. "Are you answering the question for me?” In terms of results, Belfort is in the midst of his worst run since 2005, when he lost three in a row against Randy Couture , Tito Ortiz and Alistair Overeem in the UFC and PRIDE. Numbers doesn’t matter to “The Phenom”, though. "Who said it’s complicated? I fought the two best fighters in the division, so it’s actually not complicated, it’s an opportunity for me to rewrite my story,” Belfort said. "It was a misstep. That’s the problem in fight (business). People have the loss as the worst moment, but it's the best moment, the time where I can rewrite my story again. "Unfortunately, that’s how men see things. When someone loses, they want to bury them. They create the idol, and then wants to destroy the idol. It’s a cultural thing. People need to see difficulties as an opportunity. That’s the way I see it." Belfort finished Dan Henderson by first-round knockout in November of 2015, but that impressive victory is sandwiched between TKO losses to Chris Weidman , who held the UFC title at that time, and middleweight contenders Ronaldo Souza and Gegard Mousasi . "People talk about losses, but my last fights were against the toughest guys,” Belfort said. "Nobody wants to fight these guys. Everybody is running away from them. It’s obvious that I didn't fight the way I should, but there’s the mistakes I made in the fight and there’s their qualities, too. You can’t define a person by two fights. That’s what needs to change. To rewrite my story, to learn new things, to grow. To look ahead. There’s light at the end of the tunnel. Come on!” To bounce back, Belfort changed a few things ahead of his clash with Gastelum in Fortaleza. “The Phenom” is now training with Anderson Franca, striking coach of Edson Barboza , and added MMA veterans Cassiano Tytschyo and Sergio Junior to his camp, along with Rafael Romano from natural gymnastics. "My head coaches are Joana, Davi, Vitoria and Kyara,” said Belfort, citing his wife and kids. "When there’s a change, everything changes. Not only from me, but everything around me needed to change, too. You have to change everything around you." Motivated for another UFC main event in his native country, Belfort is excited to face a talent like Gastelum, but says it wasn’t the original idea for his next bout. "They offered me (Derek) Brunson and I said yes, but he didn't accept to fight me,” Belfort said. "After that, Kelvin asked to fight me and I accepted it. Here we are. I’m a man who likes challenges. "It’s always good to know that people want to fight you,” he continued. "You're a legend and people want to prove themselves, test themselves, and for me it’s important. The same way I’m a motivation for the young (generation), I have them as motivation for me. I want to test myself. "I think it’s going to be great,” Belfort added. “I want to fight those who are at the top, those who want to fight me. He’s aggressive and comes forward. It’s a good match-up. I think it’s going to be a great test, a great competition for me. I’m motivated and confident. I’m sure of the victory." The 39-year-old Brazilian will celebrate the 20th anniversary of his UFC debut a month before the Gastelum fight, and is baffled by the way some fighters act today, especially in the middleweight division. "I see fighters choosing fights, turning down fights,” Belfort said. "The current champion, the p*ssy (Michael) Bisping not wanting to fight anyone, (Chris) Weidman choosing fights, (Luke) Rockhold running from fights, people saying they are injured. "It's sad to see the sport… How many times did the Chicago Bulls lose to the Los Angeles Lakers, and how many times did they win? We have to stop saying that’s it’s over when someone loses. It’s part of the sport. The important thing is to compete against the best. That’s one of my qualities.” Latest From Our Partners
